Award.AbstractNarration:
The NSF-supported Afranaph Project has for nearly a decade developed a research model and infrastructure for theoretical and empirical inquiry designed to uncover and record the rich empirical patterns to be found in African languages and to share these results though an internet interface and freely-accessible database. The empirical inquiry is largely conducted through internet communications with native speakers of African languages who are themselves linguists. Most of them live in Africa, and many are Ph.D. candidates who learn through their collaboration with Afranaph researchers. In recent years, Afranaph has undergone dramatic expansion, and so its internet-based community of scholars is ever larger, including more than fifty researchers, consultants, and researcher-consultants, in addition to participating graduate and undergraduate students and post-docs. This award will support a workshop at Rutgers, the PI's home institution, to bring together researchers and consultants, many who have worked together without ever meeting face-to-face, to report on empirical and theoretical results achieved so far and to plan future work.

The workshop is expected to be a galvanizing experience for the project, lead to new collaborations, and expand the professional networks of many scholars who are otherwise somewhat isolated (particularly those from Africa), while providing an excellent audience for the presentation of research results on theoretically informed language comparison. Researchers and consultants will report on the progress and goals of their research, theoretical results achieved and what sorts of further questions can now be explored, based on the comparison of rich data-sets produced by Afranaph for languages that have long been under-reported. The intellectual impact of the Afranaph Project will be cumulative, but the workshop will provide a snapshot of what it has achieved, and showcase a model for research that we expect to have broadening impact within our discipline.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Afranaph Project Development Workshop

             The Afranaph Project, supported by several NSF grants over the last ten years, accesses both the resources of the internet and the expertise of native speakers of African languages who have been trained as linguists in order to elicit rich and specialized data aimed at discovering new empirical patterns within the African languages that are relevant to research questions in theoretical linguistics. The goal of our research is to understand the nature of the human language faculty but expanding our understanding of linguistic diversity, particularly the linguistic diversity of Africa. BCS-1256137 provided support for a workshop we hosted a two day workshop in December, 2013 at Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey, the PI’s home institution, to bring together researchers and consultants, many who have worked together within the Afranaph Project without ever meeting face-to-face (most of our work is conducted on the internet), to report on the empirical and theoretical results that have been achieved so far and to plan for the work that is to be done in the future.

A major goal of the project is to make sure that all interested parties can use the results of our research, but the project’s research model and research infrastructure have both undergone dramatic expansion, and as a result the internet-based community of scholars we have assembled is ever larger. The project now includes more than fifty researchers, consultants, and researcher-consultants, in addition to participation by graduate and undergraduate students at Rutgers, New Brunswick, and postdocs supported by BCS-0919086. All of the data collected and vetted by Afranaph and all of our technical reports and grammar sketches are freely available on our website (http://www.africananaphora.rutgers.edu/) and the data is also accessible from a database of our design that anyone can use in principal, but open discussion about how to make the data most useful proceeds most quickly when the principals are in the same room.

The workshop turned out to be a galvanizing experience for the project, leading to new collaborations, expanding the professional networks of many scholars who are otherwise somewhat isolated (particularly the participants that come from Africa), while at the same time providing an excellent audience for the presentation of research results on theoretically informed language comparison. Presentations included analyses of patterns newly discovered by our researchers working on under-reported languages of Africa (including Amharic, Babanki, Chichewa, Joola Eegimaa, Fe’efe’e, Ibibio, Kinande, Kinyarwanda, Limbum, Lubukusu, Makaa, Medumba, Xhosa, Zulu), some theoretical results that have been achieved and suggestions about which theoretical questions our project is now in a good position to explore. Many young African scholars, several of them presenting their work for the first time in the West, had the opportunity to reach a diverse audience of linguists, an audience that included several senior scholars whom their work might not otherwise have reached. We expect the intellectual impact of the Afranaph Project to be cumulative, but the workshop served to provide a snapshot of what our project has achieved, what we expect it can achieve, as well as proposals for some specific ways to go about it.

The Afranaph Project currently includes six sister projects which use Afranaph resources to gather data relevant to research questions that define each sister project.
